document.title: Washington, DC K-12 Social Studies Standards Revised Standards

3637A0F85A3041E9B88D8C536B03185A.description:
Identify a current sustainability challenge and develop an action plan for increasing sustainability in the community or
globally.

6525F8EFC32D4112AF6908891C7C7470.description:
Evaluate local and global methods of human-environment interactions (e.g., farming, other forms of water and land use) to
identify practices that may be considered sustainable.

19405D02EC8E4165A2F71A8EAB75EB4C.description: Explain how the climate has changed from long ago to today and explain how the changing climate impacts life on Earth.

05F03BD19E3E4A5AA9FF25928D22D735.description: Explain how people use water and land today to produce or grow food.

2152C2D9CD9E4886855A88BF10E52D72.description:
In the final driving concept of Grade 2, students will apply what they have learned about the past to analyze the ways people use
land and water today. Students will analyze current agricultural practices to make a claim about the role of sustainability and
make a claim about what kinds of practices best ensure a healthy future.

201D9170460440F6B3D9F41DE6F971D6.description: Compare the social or political structures of societies in Africa, Europe, the Americas, and Asia between 1200 and 1600.

1C61D75F4544440C9966A92D9458524F.description:
Compare gender roles and the daily lives of individuals across societies in Africa, Europe, the Americas, and Asia between
1200 and 1600, and explain how women exercised power in different contexts.

F1EB8EB75AF84073857EDA13CEFA6D09.description:
Analyze primary sources to describe at least two of the significant architectural, cultural, and technological innovations of
the Aztec and Incan Kingdoms between 1200 and 1600

2D82D118F28A4118861FAB3FB0304BC1.description:
Analyze primary sources to describe at least two of the significant architectural, cultural, and technological innovations of
the Ottoman, Safavid, or Mughal Empires between 1200 and 1600.

B18144A03BC142E79F3D9C144B1464DD.description:
Analyze primary sources to describe at least two of the significant architectural, cultural, and technological innovations of
the monarchies in England, Spain, or France between 1200 and 1600.

12B2D787AB6A4AAA9D73A3D51366DBAF.description:
Analyze primary sources to describe at least two of the significant architectural, cultural, and technological innovations of
the empires in Mali, Songhai, or Gedi between 1200 and 1600.

2486679549EF4C9C8A5E995996CBB1BA.description:
In this driving concept, students will analyze the growth of societies between 1200 and 1500. Students will analyze how societies
grew and organized into kingdoms and cities, how they functioned as communities, and the impact of their technology,
government and innovations today.Â

6EE5AEBC51F7463DBCF7B845D1CF969A.description: Driving Concept 4: Kingdoms, Cities and Communities

F29D61917607423E90E65157CC6B14CE.description:
Analyze the daily lives of different individuals in ancient societies including histories of same-sex relationships and gender
fluidity in civilizations.

4B1F18FCAE084475BF146E6EE77C0862.description:
Describe governing and social structures developed in the Americas, Ancient Rome, and ancient China, including female-led
kingdoms and matriarchal societies.

B94C3125A4764DCDA0E777B02D42930E.description:
Compare the scientific and technological innovations across the Americas, Ancient Rome, and Ancient China (e.g., alphabets
and language systems, roads, aqueducts, etc.).

62CC56BB276D491DAFBB9C866AC37FAA.description:
Compare the physical structures constructed across the Americas, Ancient Rome, and Ancient China and analyze the
purposes of these structures (e.g., temples, pyramids, walls, etc.).

1B29E9A7FE6F4D0F96E772F69BDB1B13.description: Compare the crops grown in ancient civilizations across the Americas, Ancient Rome, and Ancient China.

C9F6C7953D7F477384948A3EF9B3D0CA.description: Explain the utility of different artifacts ââ such as photographs, renderings, petroglyphs, cave dwellings, etc. ââ and textbased sources in answering questions about the past.

A6CB85C6DFD544AF913C264FE8C6B26D.description:
Locate and identify key geographic characteristics of Central America, South America, Ancient China, and Ancient Rome
(e.g., bodies of water, landforms, climate, etc.).

BD6AE1342BF54301A409A2B98AA7E010.description:
In this driving concept, students will analyze how people lived long ago in other places of the world. Students will study empires
across the Americas, as well as civilizations that developed in other parts of the world, such as Southern Europe, Eastern Asia, orÂ Eastern Africa. Students will evaluate the role physical geography played in the development of scientific and technological
innovations across civilizations.Â

2B0A8A337AF04576A59FC0321AF0EF5F.description: Driving Concept 3: Innovations of Long Ago

EBBE74FED3C947F9BA5984089B177D38.description:
Compare and describe basic features of government of early civilizations, such as the priesthoods and kings of
Mesopotamia, the pharaohs of Egypt, monarchy of Olmec, and the ruling queens of Kush (e.g., identify patrilineal and
matrilineal practices; Hatshepsut was a female pharaoh of Egypt, etc.).

7C2EA332B70C4940A5655D79631C9A37.description:
Compare scientific, religious, and technological innovations of early civilizations, such as the ziggurats of Mesopotamia, the
pyramids of Egypt and Kush, and Olmec architecture.

5399B509A3674A4CAB4B866073687B8A.description: Compare cultural elements of early civilizations, such as forms of writing or art in Egypt, Kush, Mesopotamia, and Olmec.

E012D220D2C4406A9E2F5A0177137E97.description:
Compare the different kinds of jobs or social roles of ancient people in Egypt, Kush, Mesopotamia, and Olmec and how they
were filled by people of different genders.

42373D02C83B4F2D8FAFC37EBE59B47C.description:
Compare examples of how food was grown in ancient civilizations such as Egypt, Kush, Mesopotamia, and Olmec to how
food is grown by people around the world today.

EAFDF38F3D5F402A83BA17B2BB676C2F.description:
Explain the importance of using water to grow a food source and the importance of developing systems of irrigation,
especially in early civilizations, such as Egypt, Kush, Mesopotamia, and Olmec.Â

C2489E895AFB48B98485EB3329A91AAC.description:
Describe characteristics of âancient civilizations,â with a focus on using water and land for large-scale farming and explain
that governments helped oversee the distribution of resources.*

DF836E1FC39F41BEAD0DA06C0AEF52D2.description:
Analyze artifacts ââ such as photographs, renderings, petroglyphs, cave dwellings, etc. ââ and text-based sources to explain
how historians learn about the past.

3F09B3165F804D5F987286B7F6EB65F6.description:
Through this driving concept, students will develop historical and geographic inquiry skills to evaluate how historians know what
they know about the past. Students will evaluate the accomplishments of ancient Egypt, Kush, Mesopotamia, and Olmec
societies to understand how people used water and land to develop large-scale farming methods. Students will use primary
sources to analyze the scientific and technological innovations of ancient societies, and make comparisons between ancient
societies and contemporary life.

1DB3A8020A57404F8F45E111851E7F6B.description: Compare different ways people get food and water today locally, nationally and globally.

CBA0D406B05E47888EFCC0DA1724CEF8.description: Explain the difference between needs and wants, and identify the essential needs of all humans.

95CC4E60FC9A443DBEB6A1AD2D5FFBE1.description: Analyze data, images, maps, and texts to compare how different people around the world live today.

CD23E2262AF243C5B87DCAE7403351B0.description: Identify and explain the different climate or weather patterns in different global regions.

408BF7E0F64C485ABA628959D118D76E.description:
Identify and locate the seven continents and five oceans using maps, and describe major geographic features around the
world (e.g., coast, bay, gulf, sea, delta, river, lake, peninsula, plain, mountain, canyon, volcano, etc.).

12770E090D3C46189C9DA5AD9346EF47.description:
Create and compare visual representations (e.g., mind maps, concept mapping, spider diagrams) of communities and school
spaces.

18C609757AE7457BA3DA204E2AEFF82C.description:
Compare different kinds of maps, with a focus on physical and political maps, and identify key parts of a map (e.g., title of
map, legend or key, scale, compass or cardinal directions, etc.).

22294EB3061F4328A2035CC0F8A72829.description:
Compare different representations of the Washington, DC and Chesapeake region, including maps representing the political
geography of Indigenous Nations, to develop claims about the changes to the region over time.

5B67587A6DEB4ECE98EFBE2F6468A146.description:
In this driving concept, students will compare life in the past to life in the present using political and physical maps, as well as
other image and text-based resources, to develop their mapping skills and understanding of geography. Beginning with a lens of
inquiry, students will first analyze their own lens or position in the world, identifying their âlocalâ sense of place to position
themselves within the context of the larger world. Students will analyze ways people engage with the environment and the
impact of the environment on human interactions.

9272B041D99F48ED96931CF32CD89A7E.description: Driving Concept 1: Understanding Ourselves in the Larger World
